author: trent_vanepps
content:
> Maybe we could introduce some sort of End of Life process for opcodes, precompiles, transaction types, etc.?

i think this is a good idea <@!301186049323958275>

author: vorot93
content: https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/eip-for-disabling-selfdestruct-opcode/4382

author: sky.cactus
content: <@329594653097721856> If you want to champion removing self destruct I think there is a reasonable amount of support for it in the core devs.  I think to get *enough* support to push it through you'll need to troll through all existing contracts and do a pretty thorough review of what (if anything) will break in a way that is unrecoverable or (worse) un-preparable.  For example, are there any contracts with something like `require(now >= year2022); selfdestruct(owner);`.

author: sky.cactus
content: If there is nothing insane like that (I doubt there is), then I think it will just be a matter of setting a date sufficiently in the future for an end of life policy to get enough buy-in from core devs.

author: trent_vanepps
content: will require significant outreach

author: sky.cactus
content: I think the primary reason #2751 died off is just because no one was really championining it (e.g., pushing it through the EIP process, soliciting feedback, integrating feedback, researching edge cases, etc.)

author: madeof_tin7509
content:
re:outreach

Support for communite members effected would go a long way with making the change palatable for the community.

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Things like what happened with Aragon are likely to happen again

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Which means resrouces and time and what not.

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Making breaking changes and leaving developers to the wolves (after they have paid for audits and such) is gonna get a lot of push back.

author: trent_vanepps
content: cataloguing affected contracts there are and the impact would be a good first step

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Yep

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Which is also a resoures/time question

author: sky.cactus
content: I kind of suspect that the set of impacted contracts will be mostly gas token stuff.

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Starting with a champion most likely

author: timbeiko
content: Agenda for the next AllCoreDevs: https://github.com/ethereum/pm/issues/237

author: samwilsn
content: How about instead of `SET_INDESTRUCTABLE`, we add an opcode `VERSION` which takes a single argument `ver_num`. The first version would make the `SELFDESTRUCT` opcode invalid ðŸ¤£

author: axic3354
content: There is a very large number of issues discussing the various kind of versioning to have. What you describe is one of the oldest proposals ðŸ™‚

author: samwilsn
content: Yep, I'm not making a serious suggestion lol

author: axic3354
content: One of the main complaints about versioning was the complexity it introduces, i.e. what and when can be deprecated. One fear was that it would just mean that an increasing number of versions of EVM needs to be supported. Perhaps with something like regenesis this is not such a big issue anymore, as old versions can be disabled/dropped.

author: samwilsn
content: Doesn't the EVM need to support old versions anyway, to correctly rerun old blocks?

author: axic3354
content: I wonder though if it is possible to disable anything really if there is no certainty that it won't break "enough" contracts.

author: axic3354
content: With something like regenesis you would (regurarily) have a new checkpoint (new genesis) whose hash is agreed on in consensus and anyone can start processing from that hash.

author: samwilsn
content: Right, that definitely makes it easier. Without regenesis though?

author: axic3354
content: Without it only light clients who don't want to verify from genesis can drop old hard forks / old versions.

author: axic3354
content: Probably also when the beaconchain consensus covers eth1, then it would be possible to drop legacy things?
